display_asset.caption: Benoît Violier in 2012. The French-Swiss chef was found dead on Sunday at his home in Crissier, near Lausanne, Switzerland.

summaries.body: The French-Swiss chef Benoît Violier, who ran a restaurant in Switzerland that was named the world’s best, has died in an apparent suicide, the police said. He was 44.

display_asset.caption: Michael J. Feeney

summaries.body: An ex-reporter for The New York Daily News, Michael J. Feeney, fell ill before starting a new job at CNN and died from complications from a staph infection. He was 32.

display_asset.caption: A driver was killed after a tree fell across multiple lanes of traffic and crushed her car in Pacific Beach, Calif., on Sunday.
display_asset.credit: John Gastaldo/San Diego Union-Tribune, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A powerful storm tore off rooftops and knocked out power to thousands of people in San Diego and Los Angeles. A driver was killed after a tree crashed onto her vehicle.

display_asset.caption: Pep Guardiola, left, will replace Manuel Pellegrini as Manchester City’s manager beginning next season.

summaries.body: Manchester City soccer club announced that it has signed Pep Guardiola, a managerial superstar at Barcelona and Bayern Munich, to take over next season.

display_asset.caption: A branch of the Hu Da hot pot restaurant chain in Beijing. Hu Da is one of at least 36 restaurants across China that have been investigated for illegally using poppy capsules as seasoning.

summaries.body: At least 36 restaurants across China were investigated for adding poppy capsules and other illegal ingredients to food to make it more addictive, the state news media said.

display_asset.caption: “Why do people want to get stuck in the past?” asked Anna Wintour, Condé Nast’s artistic director.

summaries.body: As artistic director, Anna Wintour has made a rash of changes at Condé Nast in an effort to keep its many magazines relevant, but they have left some employees reeling.

display_asset.caption: Myanmar’s newly democratic government has banned the export of raw timber, to help fight deforestation. But that has idled thousands of the elephants that toil in the logging industry.
display_asset.credit: Produced by By JONAH M. KESSEL
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

sectionFrontImages.caption: Mahouts and their elephants at their camp. Experts say that hard work has kept Myanmar’s elephants relatively healthy.
sectionFrontImages.credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times

display_asset.title: Myanmar’s Unemployed Elephants

summaries.body: Myanmar's recent effort to fight deforestation has idled thousands of elephants that toil in the logging industry.

display_asset.caption: The remains of a house on Crotona Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx after a fire last week. David Gonzalez, 64, was killed in the blaze.
display_asset.credit: Amir Levy for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two deadly fires in the Bronx have raised concerns about people illegally living in vacant properties.
The ride-sharing service Uber is experimenting with leaving Bop It toys in back seats to distract intoxicated passengers.
The ability to recall every moment from your life is known as “autobiographical memory,” and some researchers say it can be learned. But there are some major downsides.

display_asset.caption: Alexis Bledel, left, and Lauren Graham in “Gilmore Girls” in 2002.

summaries.body: Netflix is producing a limited revival of "Gilmore Girls" that will reunite Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel and be overseen by the series creator, Amy Sherman-Palladino.
A man who was arrested with two guns at a Disneyland Paris hotel on Thursday has no known links to terrorism but was still being detained, the French police said.

display_asset.caption: Shaun White competing in the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

summaries.body: The Winter X Games have begun in Aspen, Colo., but their biggest star, Shaun White, was "not invited." And nobody is saying why.

display_asset.caption: David Granger, editor in chief of Esquire magazine, in 2012.
display_asset.credit: Robert Caplin for The New York Times

summaries.body: David Granger, the editor of Esquire since 1997, will leave the magazine on March 31 and will be replaced by Jay Fielden, the editor in chief of Town & Country.
A man was charged in the death of his daughter after, police say, he pointed a rifle at a state constable during an eviction. The officer opened fire, killing the 12-year-old.

display_asset.caption: The statue of Jefferson Davis, the president of the Confederacy, at the University of Texas at Austin last year.

summaries.body: Around the world, student activists are demanding the removal of monuments commemorating historical figures whose legacies are now regarded as morally dubious.

display_asset.caption: Bruce Springsteen performing at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night.
display_asset.credit: Nicole Fara Silver for The New York Times

summaries.body: At Madison Square Garden, Bruce Springsteen was "committed as always to connecting with the audience," our reviewer writes of his latest concert.
The police in Tennessee say the deaths of two teenagers may be from drinking a mixture of Mountain Dew and fuel used in drag racing.

display_asset.caption: Hilaria Bustamante, 89, said she was kidnapped by the Japanese in 1943 and forced into sexual slavery.
display_asset.credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times

summaries.body: As the Japanese emperor visited their country, the so-called comfort women of the Philippines sought an apology for being forced into wartime brothels.

display_asset.caption: The statue of Cecil Rhodes on the facade of Oriel College in Oxford, England.

summaries.body: A college at Oxford University says its facade will keep a statue of Cecil Rhodes, an imperialist benefactor seen by many as an architect of apartheid.
A bill that would give City Council members a raise far above the level recommended by a panel may come to a vote the same day as the mayor's horse-carriage plan.

display_asset.caption: A search-and-rescue mission at an apartment that was destroyed by an explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Tex., in 2013. A total of 15 people died.

summaries.body: Many fertilizer plants are too close to schools, parks and housing, according to a federal report on the 2013 explosion in West, Tex., that killed 15 people.

display_asset.credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

summaries.body: Hundreds of manhole covers across New York City have exploded since last week’s blizzard. This is not uncommon.
A teenager in Australia, who pleaded not guilty to terrorism charges, is accused of planning an attack on the police by planting explosives on a kangaroo.

display_asset.caption: David Lee Roth performing with Van Halen in 2012. This year, Acura is using a classic Van Halen song in its Super Bowl 50 ad for the 2017 NSX sports car.
display_asset.credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times

summaries.body: Acura taps Van Halen to use their song "Runnin' With the Devil" for a Super Bowl commercial, but the use of well-known songs can be a high-risk, high-reward proposition.

display_asset.caption: Drafting Kristaps Porzingis, right, has changed the trajectory of the Knicks’ organization.
display_asset.credit: Kamil Krzaczynski/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

summaries.body: In his first full season as president of the Knicks, Phil Jackson said his experiment had “fallen flat on its face.”

display_asset.caption: Clay tablets, including one at the left, revealed that Babylonian astronomers employed a sort of precalculus to describe Jupiter’s motion across the night sky relative to distant background stars. They did this 15 centuries earlier than Europeans were first credited with making such measurements.
display_asset.credit: Left to right: Trustees of the British Museum/Mathieu Ossendrijver; NASA

summaries.body: Markings on a small clay tablet indicate that ancient Babylonians used a sort of precalculus technique to track Jupiter’s orbit, a new article reveals.
A lawyer for Volkswagen said the company might have to buy back some of the cars that were rigged to cheat emissions tests because it would take too long to fix them.

display_asset.caption: Craig Moon, who was named publisher of The Las Vegas Review-Journal on Thursday.
display_asset.credit: Michael Temchine for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Las Vegas Review-Journal has named Craig Moon to be its publisher. He spent nearly 30 years at Gannett Newspapers, rising to president and publisher of USA Today.

display_asset.caption: Ethan Couch, known as the “affluenza teen” after he killed four people in a drunken-driving crash in 2013, left Mexico City headed for Texas on Thursday.

summaries.body: Ethan Couch, the teenager whose lawyers cited "affluenza" after he killed four people in a drunken-driving crash, returned to Texas from Mexico, where he had fled.
